snippet: Britain’s hacking scandal spilled into television as Sky News, whose parent company is controlled by Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation, said a reporter had accessed e-mails.
abstract: Sky News, a satellite news broadcaster whose parent company British Sky Broadcasting, or BSkyB, is controlled by Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation, admits that one of its reporters had hacked into e-mails on two occasions while pursuing news stories; it is the first time that Britain’s hacking scandal has spilled into television news; admission comes just after James Murdoch resigned as chairman of BSkyB; Sky claims the hacking was editorially justified.

byline.original: By SARAH LYALL and RAVI SOMAIYA

lead_paragraph: Britain’s hacking scandal spilled into television as Sky News, whose parent company is controlled by Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation, said a reporter had accessed e-mails.

headline.main: British Broadcaster With Murdoch Link Admits to Hacking
headline.print_headline: Hacking Case Hits British TV For First Time

keywords.value: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
keywords.name: subject
